title: Social Work Group Practice Exam Set 3
description: Comprehensive examination covering social group work concepts, practices, and applications. Set 3 of 3. All questions written in clear, student-friendly language with practical examples and step-by-step explanations.

questions.question: According to Wilson and Ryland (1949), social group work is:

options.B: A process where group interaction is purposefully guided toward agreed aims

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - A process where group interaction is purposefully guided toward agreed aims

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Individual therapy in groups) - This focuses on individuals rather than understanding how the whole group develops and changes.
• **C** (Random group gatherings) - This misunderstands the purposeful nature of social work groups, which are intentionally designed to help people.
• **D** (Community organizing only) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: The treatment procedure in remedial group work approach includes all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: C** - Community organizing

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Intake and diagnosis) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **B** (Group composition) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Evaluation and termination) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Which author emphasized that group work helps individuals enhance social functioning through purposeful group experiences?
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Perlman and Murphy

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Mary Richmond) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Sigmund Freud) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Karl Marx) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Trecker (1965) defined social group work as helping members in groups through:

options.B: Facilitated interchange in programs toward maturation

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Facilitated interchange in programs toward maturation

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Individual counseling only) - This focuses on individuals rather than understanding how the whole group develops and changes.
• **C** (Passive observation) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (External control) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**

• **D** (Emmanuel Tropp) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

questions.question: A key difference between treatment and task groups is:

options.B: Treatment groups bond for personal needs; task groups gather to accomplish tasks

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Treatment groups bond for personal needs; task groups gather to accomplish tasks

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Size only) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Location of meetings) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Cost of services) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Theoretical base) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Educational requirements) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Agency settings) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

questions.question: The "here-and-now" focus in group work means:

options.B: Emphasizing current interactions and experiences in the group

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Emphasizing current interactions and experiences in the group

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Ignoring the past) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Planning only for today) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Avoiding future planning) - Ignoring or avoiding issues is not an effective social work approach - problems need to be addressed directly.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: In group work, "mutual aid" refers to:

options.B: Members helping each other achieve goals

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Members helping each other achieve goals

**Why this is correct:** William Schwartz discovered that people in groups can help each other solve problems better than a worker helping each person individually. It's like having a team where everyone contributes their strengths.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Financial assistance programs) - Mutual aid in social work isn't about money - it's about people supporting each other emotionally and socially.
• **C** (Agency funding) - Mutual aid happens between group members themselves, not from the agency providing support.
• **D** (Professional networking) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on William Schwartz's mutual aid model (1961)

questions.question: The concept of group autonomy emphasizes:
questions.explanation:

• **A** (Worker control) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Agency mandates) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (External supervision) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

questions.question: The Developmental Approach's three major themes include all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: C** - Psychoanalytic

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Humanistic) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **B** (Phenomenological) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **D** (Developmental) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.

questions.question: In the Remedial Model, the worker as "central person" functions as:

options.B: Object of identification with authority and control

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Object of identification with authority and control

**Why this is correct:** This approach focuses on changing specific problem behaviors through group influence, similar to how group therapy works to address particular issues.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Friend to members) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **C** (Passive observer) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.

options.B: Follow mandatory reporting while supporting the student

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Follow mandatory reporting while supporting the student

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Keep it confidential) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Confront teacher directly) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Tell parents only) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: During termination, members want to continue meeting independently. This indicates:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Successful mutual aid development

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Dependency) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Group failure) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Need for extension) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A member consistently monopolizes group time with crises. The worker should:

options.B: Set boundaries while addressing pattern with group

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Set boundaries while addressing pattern with group

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Allow it to continue) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Provide individual therapy) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Remove the member) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: In a men's group, emotions are expressed through anger only. The worker should:

options.B: Help expand emotional vocabulary and expression

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Help expand emotional vocabulary and expression

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Accept this as male culture) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Prohibit anger) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Focus on behavior only) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A refugee support group has language barriers. The best approach is:

options.B: Use interpreters and multiple communication methods

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Use interpreters and multiple communication methods

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (English only policy) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Separate by language) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Focus on nonverbal only) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: During a group for abuse survivors, a member has a flashback. The worker should:

options.B: Provide immediate grounding while involving group support

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Provide immediate grounding while involving group support

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Continue group process) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Call emergency services) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (End the session) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A worker notices romantic attraction between teen group members. This should be:

options.B: Addressed regarding group dynamics and boundaries

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Addressed regarding group dynamics and boundaries

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Ignored) - Ignoring or avoiding issues is not an effective social work approach - problems need to be addressed directly.
• **C** (Encouraged) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Reported to parents) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards
